Justification: To assess for any visible abnormalities, such as swelling, discoloration, or deformities.
To evaluate tenderness, temperature differences, and to assess for any masses or abnormalities.
To quantify the degree of swelling and compare it to the left calf.

Physical Exam: Assessment of range of motion in the ankle and knee
Justification: To determine if movement exacerbates the pain and to assess for any limitations.

Physical Exam: Doppler examination of the lower extremities
Justification: To evaluate for venous or arterial flow issues, which may indicate deep vein thrombosis or other vascular problems.
To assess for the presence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) by eliciting pain in the calf upon dorsiflexion of the foot.

Physical Exam: Neurological examination of the lower extremities
Justification: To assess for any neurological deficits that may be contributing to the pain.

Physical Exam: Assessment of pulses in the lower extremities
Justification: To evaluate arterial circulation and ensure there are no vascular issues.

Physical Exam: Examination of the feet and ankles
Justification: To check for any signs of injury, swelling, or other abnormalities that may be related to the calf pain.

Physical Exam: Assessment of vital signs again if necessary
Justification: To ensure that there are no changes in the patient's condition during the examination.
